name: Icelandic Phallological Museum - World's Only Penis Museum
description: The Icelandic Phallological Museum holds the unique distinction of being the world's only museum dedicated exclusively to phallology (the scientific study of the penis), housing the planet's largest collection of penises and penile parts with over 300 specimens representing more than 100 different mammal species. Located in downtown Reykjavík at Hafnartorg Square near the harbor, this one-of-a-kind museum presents what could easily be dismissed as a novelty attraction with unexpected scientific rigor, educational context, and even artistic sensibility, creating an experience that manages to be simultaneously educational, fascinating, humorous, and genuinely unique. The collection began in 1974 when Sigurður Hjartarson, then a teacher and historian, received his first specimen—a bull's penis used as an ox-whip—as a joke gift, sparking what would become a lifelong passion for assembling this extraordinary collection. Over the following decades, Hjartarson methodically acquired specimens from Icelandic mammals including whales, seals, walruses, polar bears, foxes, minks, and all land and marine mammals found in Iceland, as well as donations from around the world including elephants, giraffes, and primates. The museum's crown jewels include massive whale penises up to 170 centimeters long and weighing 70 kilograms, displayed alongside tiny hamster specimens barely visible to the naked eye, creating startling contrasts in size and biological diversity. Each specimen is carefully preserved, labeled with species information, and accompanied by educational explanations about reproductive biology, evolutionary adaptations, and the role these organs play in different mammalian mating strategies. The museum's current location, acquired in 2011, provides triple the exhibition space of the original, allowing for improved displays, interactive features, and even a phallic-themed bistro for visitors seeking refreshment. Interactive elements include opportunities to learn about folklore and mythology surrounding male genitalia across cultures, artistic representations throughout history, and the surprising cultural significance of these organs in Icelandic and international contexts. The museum takes its educational mission seriously while acknowledging the inherent humor many visitors find in the subject matter—the tone balances scientific information with playful presentation, creating an atmosphere that encourages both learning and laughter. Visitors will encounter specimens ranging from the sublime to the bizarre, including lampshades made from bull scrotums, artwork featuring phallic imagery, and even alleged samples from Icelandic folkloric creatures like elves and trolls (presented with tongue firmly in cheek). The museum has become a must-visit Reykjavík attraction for tourists seeking unusual experiences, featured in countless travel guides, TV documentaries, and viral social media posts as one of the world's strangest museums.
